user.biography: Home to Bruichladdich, Port Charlotte and Octomore Islay single malts. We’re proud to be the first Scotch whisky distillery to be B Corp certified.

node.text:
Head Distiller Adam Hannett and Production Director Allan Logan recorded live on Bruichladdich Day, tasting our festival bottle and our house whisky side by side. 

If it’s making your mouth water, you can enter our ballot for the Laddie Origins til 12:00 noon BST tomorrow. And help yourself to a Classic in the meantime. See link in bio.

#timetravellers #feisile

node.text:
Live from outside distillery gates, Frazer provides an update on what’s been and what’s still to come.

Link in our bio to join in the fun over the next 90 minutes!

node.text:
Live cocktail session with Ewald @talkin_laddie
 
Our man in Germany, Switzerland and Austria created a drink inspired by the famous Foo Fighters song. It pretends to be a heavy winter drink but is actually a crisp summer refreshment with a deep red colour.

Here is the recipe:

5 cl Classic Laddie infused with lemon thyme and black mallow
3 cl homemade smoky Blueberry syrup
1 cl Tawny Port
1 bar spoon Balsamic Vinegar
Ginger Ale
Decoration: Orange peel and lemon thyme

You will find more info about how to prep the ingredients in the download pack for the Time Travellers festival. Register for the festival via link in bio.

node.text:
Talking B Corp over a few drinks. 
Community, Environment, Governance, Workers and Customers - what does it mean to be measuring our impacts in these areas? And how tasty is a tea / tisane + whisky combo!?

Recipes:

🌱 Peppermint Julep 
50ml Classic Laddie
1 Teapigs Peppermint tea temple
50ml boiled water
2 tsp brown sugar
ice
shaker
fresh mint for garnish

Brew your peppermint tea for 5-10 minutes in 50ml of freshly boiled water – the longer you brew, the mintier the final flavour.
Add sugar while it’s still hot, then allow it to cool.
Add whisky and shake with ice.
Strain into an old fashioned glass over crushed ice and garnish with fresh mint.

🌻 Chamomile Sours 
50ml Classic Laddie
1 Teapigs Chamomile tea temple
50ml boiled water
30g sugar
30ml lemon juice
30ml aquafaba or 1 egg white

Brew your chamomile tea for 5 – 10 mins in 50ml freshly boiled water.
Add sugar while it’s still hot, then allow it to cool.
Add to shaker with the other ingredients and shake for 1min without ice. Then add ice and shake again until cool.
Strain into old fashioned glass.

node.text:
Adam and Frazer tasting our newly released Islay barley vintage against the previous year’s. 

Apologies for the connectivity issues, they don’t seem to be something we can resolve in-house. But we will repost this chat with the missing pieces in the next few days. Slainte!

node.text:
For anyone who missed Nick's episodic Sunday show matching malts and music, here's the full collection. 

Featuring 10 Bruichladdich Islay Barley, Organic, PC10, PC MRC 01, Octomore 10.1, 10.3, 10.4, Black Art 6, Bere Barley 2010 & Classic Laddie paired with eclectic, thought-provoking, (fairly obscure) (usually Belgian) records... 

Knock yourselves out over the holidays :) 

@nick_baeyens fanclub starts here.

node.text:
This week we excitedly saw the rye from @coullfarmislay go through our mash tun, so here are some musings with farmer Andrew Jones on their 2020 barley harvest.

Andrew, his father Donald and fiancée Sophie brought in the barley this September, “The best harvest weather we’ve had since growing for Bruichladdich”. Donald was growing barley on the farm for over 30 years before Bruichladdich barley was even a thought: “He’s the man that knows the farm, he knows if a field has barley in it it will need X ,Y and Z. He’s keeps and eye from the moment the combines are going to the end, he keeps me right!’. 
🌾
Andrew says 2018 harvest was a record year and while 2019 tonnage was down a little, 2020 was up again. The last load into the shed was brought in by Donald in his ATV trailer, a real family effort.

Thank you, thank you, thank you to all our barley growers across the country in this unexpected year. Farming never rests.
🌾
Look out for the full interview audio with Andrew next week.
🚜
Thanks to @sophiemacgillxo and @jonesy871 for sharing your footage.

#islaybarley #isleofislay #islaywhisky

node.text:
Meanwhile, in Orkney… 
-
Our newest grower, Erik Stout, and his neighbour and retiring grower Sydney Gauld, check moisture levels on the bere barley harvest. With 30 cows on his farm, which looks over Kirkwall bay, Erik was also interested in the good amount of straw he could get off the field. He’s tried and tested 3 of our previous bere barley vintages and is delighted that he’ll be able to give his visitors a dram of something that was actually grown on the farm in future. 
-
The bere was all safely stowed by September 5th, thanks to a sustained spell of high pressure. 

John Wishart, one of our partners at UHI Orkney, reports an unbelievably dry summer up there. The loch which supplies mainland Orkney’s drinking water fell to record lows. 

They weren’t sure how the bere barley, which is genetically so different to modern conventional varieties, was going to cope with the conditions. 

We’re pleased to report “higher-than-normal yields; lower-than-normal moisture at harvest”. The barley needs to be dried so as to be stored before it is re-awoken through malting, so if moisture levels are too high when it comes off the field it has an impact on the feasibility and sustainability of the drying process. 
-
#berebarley #farming #harvest2021 #provenance #farmtotable #whisky #scotch
With thanks to @je.wishart

node.text:
Burst hoops from a blood tub cask is just one of the things you have to deal with on a day in our warehouses… 
-
Guest Writer Hannah’s new blog recounts her whole day working alongside the boys in warehouse 12. From hushed and holy feelings to exploding flavours, physical workout to rigorous mental requirements, the warehouse has the lot. 
-
More via link in bio
#bts #warehouseforaday #whisky #islaywhisky

node.text:
There’s a new field on Islay where malting barley has been grown for us this year. It’s between the church and the lighthouse, on the road between Bruichladdich and Port Charlotte, above the twinkling waters of Loch Indaal. It belongs to Mary McGregor. 
-
Mary has worked in the Laddie Shop since 2003, and says she had wanted their family farm to be “growing for Bruichladdich” since the initiative began in 2004. Given a field for her birthday last year, she knew just what she wanted to do with it. But she was starting from scratch. Having got her first harvest home on Sunday, she shares her experiences in a new article on our website. Link in stories. 
-
#islaybarley #farmtotable #whisky #icon @mary.mcgregor.3139

node.text:
“The 1988 is a stunning example of how well Bruichladdich ages...” Adam Hannett 
- 
“It is a delicate, fruity spirit with a tremendous floral edge, all underpinned by a subtle oak presence.” This old Bruichladdich has been matured entirely in rare re-fill squat Bourbon hogsheads, never been moved. Its flavours are subtle, measured, cultivated, and absolutely definitive Bruichladdich. If you know you like our whisky, or you want to give someone a very special exemplar, you can’t do better than this from our Rare Cask Series; some of the last of its kind. 
-
POA
6000 bottles
Unpeated Islay Single Malt 
46.2% alcohol by volume. 
Thanks for the bottle photo to @_shopsk_ 
-
#dramfortheweekend #lastofitskind #rarewhisky #scotch #islaysinglemalt #islaywhisky #oldbruichladdich
#whisky #weekend

node.text:
B B B Barley
-
All grain is packed with starch, a mix of carbohydrates used to store energy. When barley grains are soaked in water and then dried at a steady temperature (malting) enzymes are released which can turn that stored starch into sugar - energy to make the plant grow - this is the start of germination. 
-
In 4000 BC in Mesopotamia barley was grown as one of the very earliest domestic grain crops - people soon found out though that if you let it sprout just a little bit it tasted sweet. You could use the partly germinated barley to make a naturally sweet tea. That tea then fermented, producing a drink that made you feel good - hurrah! Beer was born… 
-
Of course, it’s the fermentation of the sugars by yeasts that generates alcohol. Fermentation naturally drops off at about 6% alcohol by volume. That’s the “beer” or as we would call it in the business “wash”. Distil that, twice, or three, or even four times, collecting the alcohols, concentrating the flavours and natural esters, and we have whisky. Malt whisky. Made at a single scottish distillery? Single malt whisky. 
-
All starts in the field, with this most obliging of cereals. On with the harvest!
-
#islaybarley #harvest2021 #whisky #singlemalt #singlemaltwhisky #history #science #farmtotable

node.text:
There’s Octomore Islay barley in the malt bins this week. 

Each year barley from Octomore farm is harvested, malted and distilled separately to become our Octomore ‘.3’ range; a single farm, single vintage, single malt. 

#isleofislay #provenance #singlemalt #islaywhisky

node.text:
The island’s farmers are about halfway through their harvest.
-
With the prospect of a future release in hand, our #dramfortheweekend has to be Bruichladdich #islaybarley.
-
You need luck, you need balls, you need patience, you need comradeship to get a barley harvest off the fields here in Islay. It is about flavour; we think it tastes different. But it’s also the endeavour. Slaìnte!
-
#islaybarley #islaywhisky #whisky #scotch #harvest2021 #farming #fieldtofork #farmtofork

node.text:
We’re bottling Classic Laddie this week on Islay. 
-
Tomas is checking fill levels, Paul is on capsule (seal) control, Gabi is hand-packing at the end of the line. If you’re interested in Adam’s process pre-bottling, see our stories. 
-
As the bottles come down the line, they are given a batch code. You can use that code on our website to find out much more about the components of this “non-age-statement” or “multi-vintage cuvee” or whatever you want to call our signature unpeated single malt whisky. We call it “The Classic Laddie.”

node.text:
In many small communities, it takes the voluntary sector to keep the show on the road.
-
Whether that’s the PTA, local events - like the agricultural show in Islay, run by a committee since 1874 - or helping neighbours and those in need. But on an island, those people who look out for our coastlines, who have the tact and the skills to help with rescues and emergencies are significant.
-
Meet Tony @morrrison88, warehouseman and one of the 9 men and women in our team alone, who actively contribute to the voluntary emergency services. We salute you! 
-
#community #isleofislay #lifeboat @rnli

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bruichladdich Distillery in Bruichladdich Distillery, Islay. May be an image of drink and indoor.

node.text:
Seeing out the bank holiday weekend with a Port Charlotte cask exploration.
-
Which of the cask explorations is your favourite? Fine French wine, a Sicilian DOC, Eau de vie, Sherry…  The somewhat cryptic initials in the series are because we’re not legally allowed to tell you the exact chateaux where we source our wood.
-
The good news is there are plenty more exceptional casks biding their time in our warehouses where they came from! Great flavour combinations with our floral, heavily-peated Islay single malt, turning it slowly autumnal pink, or ruby, adding soft peach, dried fruit, muscularity… 
-
Browse the full range of currently available Port Charlotte whiskies via link in bio. And watch this space; next edition is on the horizon 
-
#dramfortheweekend #whisky #islaywhisky #singlemalt #scotch #cask #casks #portcharlotte

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bruichladdich Distillery on August 24, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
That’s Donald McCormick of Blackrock passing to and fro with the first of the #islaybarley harvest this afternoon.
-
The wee birdies straight in to pick up the spares! He’s headed down to get the grain weighed and dried for storing at Octofad Farm in the Rhinns.
-
The warm weather of the last few days is set to continue for another week so we expect the road in front of the distillery to be rumbling with trailers from now on. Brilliant to have so much of our barley grown within the circumference of the island now, after starting from scratch with one farmer in 2004.
-
#progress #provenance #farming #harvest #harvesthome #maltingbarley #islaywhisky #scotch #whiskystartsinthefield
